refresher.title: üè• Real-Life Story: Hospital Report Delivery
refresher.content:
# üì¶ Hospital Report Delivery System Imagine a hospital management system. A **doctor** writes a patient report. That report must be: - Displayed on the **nurse‚Äôs screen** - Shown inside the **patient summary card** But here's the rule üëá ‚ùå Nurses and cards **cannot change** the report. They can only **read what the doctor sends**. --- ## ‚ùå The Problem Without a proper delivery system: - Data gets duplicated - Child components create their own data - Inconsistencies appear everywhere --- ## üß† Why This Happens Each React component is **isolated by default**. They don‚Äôt know about each other‚Äôs data unless it‚Äôs passed explicitly. --- ## ‚úÖ React Solution: Props **Props** are how a parent component **sends data** to a child component. Props are: - Read-only - One-way (parent ‚Üí child) --- ## üîß Basic Syntax ```js function Child({ data }) { return

{data}

; } ``` üëâ **Next: Let‚Äôs deliver reports correctly.**

positive.title: ‚úÖ Positive Case: Passing Patient Data
positive.description: The doctor sends patient data to a summary card using props.
positive.explanation:
**How it works (Hospital Mapping):**

1. Doctor (parent) owns the data
2. Report is passed to the nurse card via props
3. Child displays the data
4. No direct modification allowed

‚úÖ **Key Rule:** Props flow downward only.

negative.question: Why is this code wrong?

options.explanation: ‚úÖ Correct! Props are read-only. Only the parent can change data.
JavaScript allows reassignment, but React props must remain immutable.
The syntax is valid, but the logic is incorrect.

negative.lesson:
**Real-Life Mistake:**

This is like a nurse editing the doctor‚Äôs report.
